title: Thursday, 21st February 2019
bodyHTML:
11:06 am
BE11:06am

Hello! Today we have all the news.

VV75 morning
Soundbuy Hello
BE11:07am

In a sensible and orderly universe, the news would be spread out evenly across the week so I didn't run out of things to type by 11.52am.

BE11:07am

Instead, we have Thursdays.

Blank canvas morning all
WP77 Morning
DJ Morning
11:07 am
BE11:07am

Which require me to file ~1k words for somewhere else on the website before even thinking about this thing. Good morning, BTW.

BE11:08am

So .... Where to start?

WP77 PURP?
Potter Pureplebricks?
Soundbuy Have vols taken a nosedive this morning.......a tad zzzzzzzzzz....
WP77 Apologies PurpleBricks**
Plato the Cook Begin at the beginning
Lemmy I read Kraft Heinz/3G looking for acquisitions again... BE on standby?
BE11:10am

Demand, unsurprisingly, is directed towards the gig-economy Foxtons.

11:10 am
Purplebricks Group PLC (PURP:LSE): Last: 117.60, down 47 (-28.55%), High: 127.60, Low: 99.80, Volume: 6.78m
BE11:10am

So! Revenue's going to miss by 20%

Soundbuy @Lemmy - runners and riders?
BE11:11am

Because of ...... uh ...... is this right? Because of a bad advertising campaign in the US.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Ad campaigns one and three were fine. Ad campaign two wasn't.

BornCynic Morning - do you feel up to talking about Centrica please BE? I know that utilities are not your favourite subject.
BE11:12am

Add in some problems turning around Australia and you get a 20% revenue shortfall. You also get the UK and US CEOs exiting rather suddenly.

VV75 no no, the advertising is not bad, the clients don't understand yet, so they are at fault
Lemmy Soundbuy: its peers apparently, rather than small bolt-ons, see piece in FT
Dec69 - Skeptic Purplebricks is just a crap fest of tech hope. People are needed to sell houses post the initial viewings and offer. This costs money. Simples. Disc: Short $PURP
Soundbuy Cheers........wondered who would fit the bill this side of the pond.....
BE11:13am

Co-founder Michael Bruce steps in to run the US. I think I'm on safe ground to suggest he's a somewhat divisive character.

Soundbuy I'll have a gander.............or wait for BE to give us the heads up.......... :)
11:14 am
BE11:14am

Vic Darvey takes over the UK, having just been nicked from Moneysupermarket

BE11:14am

Back to the warning. Here's Cazenove to summarise.

BE11:15am

The company announced that FY19 revenue guidance will be
in the range of £130-140m under IFRS 15 (vs previously £165-175m under IAS 18 and the company guiding for
a reduction of ~2% as a result of IFRS 15), with UK revenue growth of +15-20%. Management does not expect
Australia and the US to be sufficient to meet expectations for this year (with no formal guidance on those
divisions in place). Management also expects that the UK will achieve adj. EBITDA margin in double-digits for
FY19 (JPMe: 16.0%). Overall, clearly (again) a disappointing update by the company which underlines that
visibility remains low and trading is volatile. We also believe in particular the departure of Eric Eckardt (who
was well received among investors from our point of view) will be taken negatively this morning. While we
believe the Online agent space offers a significant growth opportunity longer term, we believe a meaningful
increase in housing transactions (particular UK but also Australia) is needed for a catalyst for a re-rating and
potential earnings upside. Short term, this is unlikely to be the case.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Trading update highlights that 1) the UK housing market continues to be challenging. However,
Purplebricks continue to maintain its 75% market share of online instructions and expect revenue growth of
+15-20% for FY19; 2) in the US, Purplebricks sees better than expected conversion however slower than
expected response to the second US marketing initiative at the end of January. Management see early positive
responses to the third initiative and model change to payment on completion. ST investment will be focused
on LA and Florida. The board does not expect US revenues to be sufficient to meet expectations for FY19; 3)
Australia – the board remains encouraged by the new leadership team but does not expect revenues to be
sufficient to meet expectations for this year and 4) Canada continues to perform well and on track to meet
management’s expectations.

doug43 Anything on Serco?
BE11:15am

Second marketing initiative at the end of January. It's February the 20th.

Forester Purplebricks - seems to be some monumental cash burn going on which to me is more worrying than bickering over sales stats.
Tom Dalgleish @Dec69 - Skeptic, the disruptor that wasn't
BE11:16am

And revenue to miss by 20%. What on earth, honestly?

Dec69 - Skeptic Indeed @Tom
Shinshin Do they still not talk about actual houses sold ?
11:16 am
BE11:16am

Citigroup:

BE11:16am

Implications — We expect shares to decline due to the 20% revenue downgrade.
To achieve group revenue guidance it required an ambitious performance in the US
(which is why we forecasted revenue estimates at the bottom of guidance). The
slower than expected performance in the US will likely not be viewed well,
particularly given the upbeat messaging by the company during the year and the
speed at which they decided to expand into new states.

BE11:17am

Go on then, make me a valuation case where youre' on for £10.7m loss in 2021 and revenue's just discovered to be a fifth short two months away from the end of the financial year because -- apparently! -- of one duff ad campaign.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Cracking stuff.

Dec69 - Skeptic @DJ, at least they're honest about Losses. Some companies just have a special unit to fake revenue.

BE11:20am

11:20 am
BE11:20am

While there will
be a tighter focus on capital allocation and advertising spend in
the near term, we expect FY19 group losses to be higher than
previously forecast. The balance sheet remains in a net cash
position. There have also been two key management changes
with the UK and US CEOs leaving the business. Given the
tough trading backdrop in its key regions and the recent changes
to customer propositions in the US and Australia, revenue
visibility is low and the near term growth outlook has weakened.
We place our forecasts and recommendation under review.

BE11:21am

And ........ Zeus Capital!

Dec69 - Skeptic @BE what's the customer acquisition cost, they're trying to be a national option, where local estate agents rule the roost. Why not turn themselves into bitcoin? Wait that's done? Maybe FinTech?
DJ @Dec sure, but all I'm saying is, brokers should know how valuation works, and shouldn't just want to appease companies they cover for the benefit of the parts of the bank with a balance sheet...
wayneJ (Ah - I think it may have been 100p --- I was just thinking in the happy world of Mr BE whether this was getting into a new league table)
BE11:21am

On 30 April 2019, we now expect the group to have circa £54m cash (our previous forecast was £70m). While the Purplebricks UK remains cash generative, we estimate Purplebricks Australia may require up to £10m cash investment to reach breakeven within 24 months and Purplebricks USA to require circa £40m p.a. We expect the group to be cashflow positive from April 2020.
Valuation: At 165p, Purplebricks’ share price, net of 23p cash per share, values the group on 3.2x our new forecast group revenue to April 2019.
We expect Purplebricks UK to generate a positive EBITDA of over £11m in the current year; double to over £24m next and continue to grow strongly (see Exhibit 1). Valuing Purplebricks UK at 150p a share (i.e. £455m) would be 5.2x FY(Apr)19E revenue; 4.0x prospective revenue and approximately 24x prospective divisional adj PAT with a PEG of under 1x.

Flaneur Do we have a line on who else might be leaving UK/EU now that the Japanese trade deal is complete?

DJ Brokers have to make predictions and generally are terrible at it

Centrica PLC (CNA:LSE): Last: 122.40, down 14.8 (-10.79%), High: 128.00, Low: 120.05, Volume: 31.24m

Eg a doctor takes circa 6 years at med school and then 8 - 10 years as a junior becoming a consultant. Yep people are happy to go to 'alternative practioneers' who claim / allege equivalence
Catgotmytongue Any BAE?
Flaneur @Lemmy - oh yes. Forgot about them....@WayneJ - I'm guessing he was on commission...
BE11:27am

Same reasons as all the other profit warnings. Tariff cap, upstream, E&P tax.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Most significantly, though, you have management making no explicit commitment to keep the divi.

wayneJ @Flaneur - this drives me mad. I used to rejects lots of startups as their numbers were unrealistic only to find I was often overridden by my seniors who frankly should have know better. Then guess who had to clean up the mess.
BE11:29am

So anyway, cash will be £350m light next year, £100m of which goes through to earnings, which is equivalent to about 2p per share.

BornCynic You missed them blaming the weather BE -"Centrica’s financial performance in 2018 was mixed, against a backdrop of volatile commodity prices, extreme weather patterns, continued competitive pressures and political and regulatory scrutiny and intervention"
BE11:29am

The slightly stale consensus was 12p for 2019, though had recently been drifting due to the relatively warm summer. You're now looking at 9p.

Forester "extreme weather patterns"? !?!
BornCynic @Forester - I know.................
FJ Centrica: They want to wait until the middle of the year to decide on the dividend.
11:30 am
BE11:30am

Morgan Stanley can summarise.

BE11:31am

We estimate ~20% downside to FY19 consensus EPS. Centrica is guiding to
£350m (midpoint) lower adjusted operating cash flow than in 2018, with around £100m impacting 2019 earnings. £100m equates to ~2p/share of EPS, implying c.9p of 2019 EPS (relative to the 11.2p delivered in 2018). Bloomberg consensus for 2019 is currently at 11.5p/share (MSe at 10.8p/share), implying c.20% downside.
No commitment to the 12p DPS. This has been removed from guidance. Given uncertainty around the tariff cap impact, commodity prices, nuclear output, and capacity payment, we would not expect clarity on the dividend until interim results at the earliest.

BE11:31am

As can Citi.

wayneJ Typically VCs and fund managers (for listed markets) are pushed to 'deploy capital'. There seems to be no realisation that the best returns are made by buying well. And there are times when deals are attractive and times when there are not. There is time clustering.
joachim Wonder if John Gapper has seen Bloomberg analysis showing Barclays having second best trading revenue performance in Q4? Pace his recent article no echoes of Deutsche Bank there
wayneJ I think, incidentally, this is an issue SoftBank are facing.
11:31 am
BE11:32am

 Citi's Take — Centrica reported its FY18 results with adjusted operating profit 3% below consensus and 2% below Citi estimates. EPS came at 11.2p, below the 11.5p guidance provided in November, which was widely expected given the warm weather in the last few months of the year. Adjusted operating cashflow was 7% ahead of our forecast at £2,245m and net debt at £2,656m.
 Outlook – Centrica is targeting FY19 adjusted operating cashflow (AOCF) of £1.8-2.0bn and net debt (adjusted for IFRS 16) range of £3.0-3.5bn. The mid-point of the AOCF reflects £350m lower yoy and Centrica stated that they expect £100m (c.2p/share) of this to fall through to EPS. The company has also announced a £500m disposal, with £230m of which through the announcement of sale of Clockwork Home Services business. Centrica is targeting £250m efficiencies during FY19 and have increased its medium term cost saving program by a further £500m.
 Implications — Based on the outlook guidance provided, FY19 EPS is likely to be in the c.9.0p range. This compare to our 10.5p and consensus of 12.0p. This is likely to be the biggest hit to the share price today. Furthermore, the distinctive absence of any form of official commitment to the current 12p DPS is also likely to be a sign the company financial metrics are becoming increasingly on the edge

BE11:32am

And RBC.

BE11:32am

We continue to see limited future growth prospects in downstream operations of CNA, with the core business shrinking and new business struggling to mature. Furthermore, lower commodity prices have put further pressure on earnings such that we do not believe that the current 12.0p/sh dividend is sustainable, as we forecast that CNA will fail to meet the current AOCF pre-requisite of £2.1-2.3bn. We now assume an 8p/sh dividend from 2019, with a 75% payout ratio from 2020 onwards.

wayneJ Incidentally just a slightly weird balance sheet question. If PurpleBricks promises to sell your house and you have paid upfront but not sold by year end should there be a balance sheet liability?
Forester @BornCynic was a bad year for my runner beans and pears but a great year for my butternut squash and leeks! Overall I would dscribe the weather s "British" !!!

We expect a slightly negative reaction to the print, with an
underwhelming cash performance in 2018 and 2019e. The key debates on
the stock remain the consequences on Typhoon of the German ban on
exports to Saudi Arabia, the US defence budget trend and the UK defence
spending in the context of political uncertainty.

And Goldman.

BE11:38am

In short: FY18 earnings performance is inline, but Net Debt is a little weaker than expected due to working capital. 2019 EPS guidance is also in line but the Net debt guidance is c.£500mn below consensus (Reuters) due to lower than expected FCF, in turn driven by higher capex requirements in the US and the timing of working capital movements related to the Qatar Typhoon contract. Overall we think this unexpected non-linear development in FCF in 2019 is disappointing, with the delta vs. consensus Net Debt equal to c.3% of the company’s equity value.

wayneJ And that Brexit should go ahead on the basis of 'good public administration'.

A. M. Morning all.
BE11:40am

FY19 EPS guidance is for mid-single-digit growth, but that would occur if FY18’s one-off charges were added back. Net debt is guided to increase slightly in FY19 - not what we hoped for. We believe it is when underlying cash flow is stronger than EBIT that BAE’s fortunes are probably turning. In short, BAE's position looks stronger, but FY19 may not be a year of marked acceleration in growth - much as we already forecast.

UBS:

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: Playtech reported FY18 revenue in-line with expectations at €1,240m (UBSe
€1,249m, cons €1,233m) with adjusted EBITDA slightly ahead at €343m (UBSe €340m,
cons €332m). Playtech have also announced the reallocation of shareholder returns,
with DPS down -33% to 24.1 €c, but a €40m share buyback announced meaning total
returns will be slightly ahead of FY18.
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: Divisionally, the B2B Gaming revenue was €566m vs. UBSe €553m, with 12% cc
regulated growth in the regulated part of the business, whilst Snaitech also delivered
results in-line, with online +27%. SunBingo contract has been renegotiated, with the
agreement extended for up to 15 years. The minimum guarantees will still be due to
mid-2021 (but with nothing further after). These guarantees will be amortised in the
P&L over the extended contract length, meaning the contract is expected to become
P&L profitable in 2019.
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: 2019 guidance: adj EBITDA in range of €390-415m vs. current consensus at €368m
and UBSe of €356m, which implies an underlying business in-line with our
expectations, with positive impacts of c€20m from IFRS16, a positive contribution to
EBITDA from Sun Bingo and that Asia remains stable with revenue at c€150m.
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: FY results in-line, positive progress in the underlying business, FY19 guidance ahead,
and the renegotiation of SunBingo removing one of the ongoing issues should be
supportive to shares today.

Tom Dalgleish @BC, glad I'm not the only muppett being guffed out by Numbermania in recent times
BE11:48am

And Morgan Stanley.

BE11:48am

Results summary. Playtech has released solid FY18 results, with EBITDA of
€343m above our €329m estimate and in the middle of the company's €320-
360m adjusted guidance range. The divisional performance shows few surprises,
with good growth in Sports (+14%) within B2B Gaming, good Online growth at
Snai (27%) and continued weakness in the Financials division. Asia remains stable
at a €150m run-rate as expected. Current trading in the regulated B2B Gaming
business is slightly improved at 7% (constant currency and excluding
acquisitions). The company guides to FY19 EBITDA €390-415m, above our €377m
forecast, but this is in-line when accounting for a €20m benefit from IFRS 16, and
weaker underlying as the company has announced a positive resolution to its
Sun Bingo contract renegotiation, which will have a positive EBITDA contribution
in 2019 (loss making in FY18 and -€12m in our FY19 forecasts). There is no
comment on GVC contract negotiations. Finally, the company has cut its final
dividend, with FY18 DPS of €0.24 (MSe €0.36) and rebalanced this with a €40m
buyback, with overall distribution remaining in-line with expectations. Overall, we
expect the results to be taken with relief today.

wayneJ @Forester - if you just post your email here we can ensure all spammers get the message :-)
11:48 am
BE11:49am

Forecast and view. For FY19, we forecast revenue of €1.59bn (+33%), EBITDA of
€377m (+14%), EPS of 52.5c (-16%) and DPS of 36.0c (flat), compared to
consensus of €1.64bn, €375m, 62c and 35c, respectively. Following today's
results, we expect consensus to rise slightly to account for IFRS impacts, but
otherwise remain unchanged. We continue to see Playtech as an attractive core
business with a cheap valuation, offset by the China overhang, regulatory risks in
key markets, disappointing growth and a weak financials business, and we rate
the shares Equal-weight with a 550p price target.

BE11:49am

And Goodbody.

Shinshin @wayne wasn't aware of Wilson case, just took a quick look. Looks like tilting at windmills, after Miller case shot herself in the foot. Miller established requirement for parliament to approve treaty action; corollary is that such an action stand by itself and is legally valid. All the referenda in the world can have whatever outcomes they like, but prliamentary action is what it is.

BE12:04pm

Barclays 4Q18 underlying P&L trends were broadly in line with expectations,
however better IB revenue feared, stronger capital, and management maintaining
its 9-10% ROTE guidance 2019/2020 should be positive for the stock today.
Management have proposed a 6.5p dividend in line with guidance and intend to
do buybacks "when appropriate" (we estimate £500mn buybacks for 2019E). We
have an Equal-weight on Barclays which trades on 0.6x TNAV for a 7.3% ROTE.
Results call is at 9:30am on 0203936299.
Revenues were £5.07bn 2/3% ahead of consensus/MSe. Barclays UK revenues
were in line with NII down 1.1% qoq. Loan growth was -0.7% with NIM down 2bp
to 3.20%. Revenues at Barclays international were also in line, but with the IB
better than expected.

12:04 pm
BE12:05pm

Total CIB revenues were 5% better with markets 4% better than MSe. In USD
FICC was down 11% yoy vs. peers down 19% yoy, and did better than feared.
Equities were down 2% yoy, and banking fees were down 2% yoy, recovering
from a slow Q3.
TNAV was 262p ahead of expectations. Results included a top up in the pension
fund, and £150mn provision top up due to Brexit prudential overlay which
affected UK consumer in particular. Underlying cost of risk was in line.
CET1 was 13.2% vs. MSe of 12.9% with RWAs down 1.3% qoq. Barclays will pay
6.5bp. Going forward capital return policy will be a progressive ordinary dividend,
supplemented by share buybacks. MSe is for 7.5p in 2019E and a £500mn
buyback.

We would flag four points with regards to Uber Eats entering the UK MP: 1) Following the launch of Deliveroo’s UK MP business, Just Eat has continued to deliver strong UK order growth with +16% in 3Q18 (vs +16% in 2Q18) and CSe +18% in 4Q18. Just Eat management have also noted that in the regions where Deliveroo have launched MP, Just Eat have not seen any meaningful impact on its business as of yet; 2) Given that Uber Eats launched a MP in Netherlands earlier this month, we believe this comes as no surprise; 3) The move into MP is, in our view, an acknowledgement from UberEats that the hybrid model offers a superior proposition for consumers vs standalone logistics; 4) it does however mark an unhelpful ramp up in competition in the UK MP space for Just Eat. Just Eat UK MP growth rates will be a major focus in FY19.

12:09 pm
BE12:10pm

What Uber Eats move does suggest is that they recognise their model is not working and that they are not gaining share. In that case, we think the more likely outcome is that Uber Eats decides at some point to acquire Just Eat (it would also make Uber Eats the #1 player in Canada, which is a key strategic target for them). Our view is that it will probably wait for 12-18 months to give the new initiative a try but it may decide that the public issues surrounding Just Eat may make now a good time to make a move. With Just Eat’s estimates suggesting that it had nearly 4x as much share of the UK food delivery market by YE17 (c. 33% vs 9% for UE / Deliveroo combined) and that gap likely to have widened, such a move would make strategic sense for Uber Eats.

Bonnemort Ta Dec69 - and ta BE.

BE12:10pm

Uh, huh.

BE12:11pm

Arguably, Uber Eats move to a marketplace could target those restaurants but we see it as too little, too late. As we argued in our major piece on Just Eat last year, the food delivery market has all the characteristics of the old Yellow Pages market , where #1 players benefited from very strong network effects given the 2-sided nature of the model (i.e. the more advertisers that list on the site, that pulls in more consumers who are looking for the widest range of products, which pulls in more advertisers looking for the widest pool of customers and so on).

In our view, Just Eat has already established a lock on the market in smaller towns which will be very hard for Uber Eats to unlock - while Uber Eats could theoretically lower its commission rates, for restaurants the key for taking a provider is not so much the fee rate but whether the product delivers customers. In that regards, we cannot see restaurants switching out of Just Eat into Uber Eats – the risk would be too great that the restaurant would lose customer orders. And, while restaurants could decide to install both Just Eat and Uber Eats order pads in their restaurants, many are unlikely to do so – particularly at the smaller, takeaway shops – because of the burdens of learning to operate a new system as well as concerns over such matters as counter space.
